page.title: 09Cotswold Slates & Dewponds
page.content: Cotswold stone slates were dug on land at Eyeford Hill. The Slate Pits Coppice now covers all the trenches and old rail lines. The stone was dug at Summertime and covered with piles of earth to keep it moist. At a certain time in Winter the church bell was rung to signal that the earth should be removed so that the frost split the strata of the stone into thin sheets- Cotswold slates. Dewponds were made at the time of the Enclosure awards where field boundaries crossed so that they supplied water to all 4 fields in the days when stock was kept on the farm. Cattle were driven over a clay-lined hollow to firm the ground so that it would catch the dew and rain.
